Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency recently issued a consent agreement and final order to Clean Harbors Deer Park, LLC, in La Porte, Texas. The company violated laws under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) related to the storage and handling of hazardous waste. The company will pay a $22,400 civil penalty and is required to take steps to protect the local community from health and environmental risks associated with hazardous waste.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epa/newsreleases/epa-fines-clean-harbors-violations-environmental-laws.html

Description: In an effort to protect local citizens from the dangers of hazardous waste, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) recently ordered Clean Harbors El Dorado, L.L.C. to pay a $581,236 penalty for improperly identifying and disposing of hazardous waste, improper storage of hazardous waste, and failure to comply with air emissions standards at its El Dorado, Ark. incineration facility.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/f23258d12c235c9b85257cd70065f4a9.html

Description: The Justice Department and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced a settlement with Clean Harbors Environmental Services to address benzene emissions from the big operator of hazardous waste treatment and disposal facilities. The company also agreed to pay a civil penalty of $300,000.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2005/September/05_enrd_476.html

Description: Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc., an international provider of environmental, energy and industrial services, has agreed to pay a $150,000 civil penalty to the United States to settle a series of alleged violations of hazardous waste regulations at its hazardous waste treatment and storage facility in Kimball, Neb.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/5618ce409d9a827d8525773e0065989a.html

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced an agreement with Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc. (Clean Harbors) based in Norwell, Mass., resolving alleged violations of the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act (EPCRA) at its industrial waste incineration facility in Aragonite, Utah. As part of the settlement, Clean Harbors has agreed to pay a penalty of $39,900 and correct violations associated with the failure to appropriately report chemicals manufactured and used on site.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/0d2abe856767d31385257b7b006808ad.html

Description: In a settlement valued at more than $1.7 million, Clean Harbors of Braintree Inc. has agreed to pay a significant penalty and perform additional projects, to settle a complaint filed by the U.S. Department of Justice on behalf of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), regarding numerous violations of hazardous waste management and emergency planning laws at the company's Braintree, Mass., facility.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department

Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency announced the resolution of a series of settlements under the Clean Water Act with Safety-Kleen Systems, Inc., in Newark, Calif., and Cargill Corporation, in Fullerton, Calif., for violations of federal oil pollution prevention regulations. Safety-Kleen will pay a $90,000 penalty and Cargill will pay a $45,000 penalty to resolve the violations at their facilities.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epa/newsreleases/us-epa-requires-california-companies-improve-oil-spill-prevention-plans.html

Description: Safety-Kleen Systems, Inc., a manufacturer and seller of industrial cleaning products and equipment, has agreed to pay a $26,782 civil penalty to the United States to settle three violations of environmental regulations related to the public reporting of toxic chemicals at its branch facility in St. Charles, Mo.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/c6d1a0aab3ef6e74852578ca005e7238.html

Description: Five companies in Washington have agreed to correct errors in reporting hazardous chemicals as required by federal laws designed to protect communities during chemical emergencies. The companies failed to report the storage of hazardous chemicals in violation of the Emergency Planning and Community-Right-to-Know Act, according to settlements with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The companies have agreed to correct the violations and pay fines.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/f2785177dcc0057085257ca600699ddc.html
Included in a dataset downloaded at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Company is plan administrator. Penalty amount reported in range of $10,001 to $50,000.

Description: Clean Harbors Arizona LLC (a subsidiary of Clean Harbors) agreed to pay $45,000 in settlement of allegations if failed to conduct daily inspections of tanks, failed to transfer hazardous waste from compromised container, and failed to amend plans to reduce hazards of fire, explosion or release of waste.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20080616195546/http://www.azag.gov/press_releases/may/2007/CleanHarborsAGADEQ.pdf

Description: Clean Harbors agreed to pay $300,000 to Illinois, Louisiana and the federal government to resolve litigation dealing with benzene emissions from its hazardous waste treatment and disposal facilities. The settlement was also announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-clean-harbors-environmental-services
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2005/September/05_enrd_476.html

Notes: Penalty $112,500 but $37,500 suspended.
